Award.AwardTitle: GEM: The Timing of Plasma Sheet Flows Relative to the Onset of Various Modes of Magnetospheric Response to the Solar Wind
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the use of plasma and magnetic field data from the NASA Themis mission in conjunction with a large variety of other, publically available data to study plasma flows in the magnetotail and their association with various types of geomagnetic activity. The primary objective is to determine the onset times of plasma flows and a variety of other signatures of magnetic and auroral activity and to obtain a statistically reliable time sequence of events that can be used to infer the order of physical processes that cause different types of activity.

To accomplish these goals a number of lists of onset times will be generated for a variety of phenomena known to occur during geomagnetic activity. These include pseudo-breakups, substorm onsets, poleward boundary intensifications, quasi-periodic substorms (sawtooth events), and steady magnetospheric convection. For each type of magnetic activity a number of signatures will be examined including auroral brightening, auroral activation, auroral expansion, onset of polar magnetic substorm, onset of Pi 2 activity, start of mid-latitude positive bays, start of field-aligned currents at synchronous orbit, and onset of synchronous dipolarization. Each onset will be characterized by a set of parameters such as location of observation, magnitude of change during initial perturbation, and state of the solar wind. Different onsets will be associated to establish discrete events consisting of a sequence of phenomena. Probability distributions of time delays between different onset times will be used to establish the typical delays and their variability. Combination of all of these delays provides the important time sequence used to infer causality.

This work is of value to the field of magnetospheric physics because it would help resolve the outstanding controversy in magnetospheric physics about which physical process causes the onset of the magnetospheric substorm. In particular it should answer the question of which direction in the tail disturbances propagate after substorm onset. As a statistical study of a large number of events it would provide greater confidence in the conclusions than have previous event studies. The work would also help understand how
plasma flows and magnetic flux transport in the tail are organized in different modes of response of the magnetosphere to the solar wind.

The database will be made available through the Virtual Magnetic Observatory at UCLA. The project will involve graduate students and an undergraduate research assistant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brilliant displays of aurora occur near midnight in both the northern and southern Polar Regions. These displays are organized in a predictable sequence called an auroral substorm and occur 2-8 times per day with duration of about three hours. Isolated substorms occur in a predictable sequence of one hour of growth, 20 minutes of poleward and azimuthal expansion, and then an hour and half of recovery to the quiet state. Associated with all phases of a substorm are strong currents in the ionosphere called electrojets that flow eastward before midnight and westward after midnight. Following the onset of the expansion phase an additional current flows westward across the region of expanding aurora. This current flows down along magnetic field lines at the east edge of the expanding aurora and upward at the west edge of the tail. The cause of the auroral substorm and its link to phenomena in the Earth’s magnetic tail has been a subject of controversy for nearly 50 years. Understanding the substorm is made more complex by the existence of other modes of behavior of the aurora. The pseudo breakup is a short duration intensification of the aurora that does not expand significantly. The poleward boundary intensification is a sudden brightening of the aurora at the poleward edge of the expanded aurora. Steady magnetospheric convection is a state of continuous aurora and magnetic activity with an expanded auroral region but no new intensifications and expansion. Sawtooth events are a quasiperiodic sequence of large substorms encompassing the entire nightside of the Earth. All of these modes of auroral response are associated with one essential feature in the solar wind. The magnetic field of the Sun carried by the solar wind is oriented antiparallel to the Earth’s dipole field. This fact has led to the concept of magnetic reconnection in which Earth’s field lines become connected to the solar wind field on the dayside and are carried by it over the polar caps to be stretched into a long, comet-like tail behind the Earth. It has been suggested that all modes of the auroral response are consequence of these stretched fields coming together at the center of the tail and reconnecting so they can return to the dayside.

 

This project focused on the study of substorms and steady magnetospheric convection and their relation to plasma flows in the tail associated with the reconnection and return of the stretched field lines. Observations made by many spacecraft show that when the auroral expansion begins there are bursts of high speed plasma flowing earthward and large ropes of twisted magnetic field lines moving away from the Earth. These are the expected signature of magnetic reconnection. We have used data from the five spacecraft mission (THEMIS) to study these flows and how they help generate the substorm. We find that at the time of auroral activation a high speed flow burst carrying strong northward magnetic field arrives near midnight between 8 and 12 earth radii behind the Earth. The plasma and flux from this and following flow bursts piles up creating an outward bulge in plasma pressure and magnetic field. Electric current that was flowing across this region is diverted at the eastern edge of the pileup region going down field lines and across the auroral expansion. At the western edge of the pile up region current returns from the ionosphere and then completes its path across the tail. Subsequent flows are diverted around the pileup region. We speculate that the particular configuration of plasma and magnetic field after the initial pileup is the cause of the current diversion and that a change in field line mapping along with outward motion of the pileup boundary explains the expansion of the aurora.
